 Uh, where to start? Well I guess it's best to look at the Church's official views on matters and discuss them. As there are three 'codes' that LaVey wrote I will break it down to a post on each.
 
 

 1. Satan represents indulgence instead of abstinence!
 2. Satan represents vital existence instead of spiritual pipe dreams!
 3. Satan represents undefiled wisdom instead of hypocritical self-deceit!
 4. Satan represents kindness to those who deserve it, instead of love wasted on ingrates!
 5. Satan represents vengeance instead of turning the other cheek!
 6. Satan represents responsibility to the responsible instead of concern for psychic vampires!
 7. Satan represents man as just another animal, sometimes better, more often worse than those that walk on all-fours, who, because of his "divine spiritual and intellectual development," has become the most vicious animal of all!
 8. Satan represents all of the so-called sins, as they all lead to physical, mental, or emotional gratification!
 9. Satan has been the best friend the Church has ever had, as He has kept it in business all these years!

 Points 1 to 3 and 7 and 8 are a reaction against the concept of 'sin' and the repression of our natural instincts. The idea of 'sin' restricts and constrains: if one performs and act which harms nobody and brings gratification, then why feel enforced shame for the act? Sexual urges are natural and entirely healthy, no matter whom you feel them for. It is merely a form of oppression, to make the masses feel guilty about their natural desires, or to demonise a group such as homosexuals. Equally if the act is actually destructive, then the concept of repentance means that the person then has their guilt artificially relieved, nothing is learned in the process and they are likely to commit the act again. 
 
 Of course the inherent contradiction in this is that we have essentially rules telling you not to follow rules! That is why I don't see any aspect of the doctrine to be a hard and fast rule, in fact there is quite a lot I don't agree with. To blindly follow these rules goes against the very spirit of them, everything requires criticism and analysis, everything is open to interpretation. That is why I see them as LaVey's guidelines, but not necessarily directly applicable to everyone else and as such not for literal adherence.
 
 Points 4 to 6 are concerned with the concept of 'do as you would have others do to you', rejecting it in favour of 'do as others do to you'. The philosophy is pessimistic about the nature of humanity, we naturally oppress each other or act as what LaVey calls 'psychic vampires', those who feed off the charity of others for nothing in return. I agree with this to an extent, I agree that people who give little to society should receive the same. I think we are increasingly keen on helping the undeserved, and that many of our policies should be tightened up. Yet to take this concept to far leaves a society only concerned with supporting the upper classes, I believe society has a responsibility to ensure the welfare of all citizens.
 
 The final point is a reminder about how the Church oppresses. By creating a group, usually a minority, to demonise it unifies the masses in blind hatred. This group has been women, scientists, Jews and (as it is at the moment) homosexuals. Without these objects of oppression, this perceived threat, it would not be able to keep its followers in line. By making them look without for an object of hate it blinds them to the folly within.
